Problem Overview

In this problem, students develop symbolic strategies for solving equations of the form px + q = r and p(x + q) = r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Students find the solutions to these linear equations using the properties of equality. Students compare this method with other methods they have used for solving equations. Students may mention finding solutions using tables and graphs.

Students also continue to solve word problems leading to inequalities of the form px + q > r or px + q < r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers.

AoL: Linear Relationships: Analysis &

Algebraic Expressions and Equations: Explore/Analysis

NWDYK

Describe the strategies you can use to solve linear equations using the properties of operations and equality.

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

Extend and apply strategies for solving equations algebraically to equations with integer, fractional, and decimal values (coefficients and constants).

Find the solutions to linear equations using symbolic methods (properties of operations and equality) including:

  • identifying and applying needed operations to both sides (such as adding 10 to both sides or dividing both sides by 2.5) in order to keep the expressions on each side of the equation equal,
  • identifying when to apply the Distributive Property as needed to reach a solution efficiently (factored or expanded),
  • applying order of operations appropriately as needed to simplify equations, and
  • understanding the goal is to isolate the variable on one side of the equation.

Connect newly developed symbolic methods for solving equations (answering questions about relationships) to prior experiences with solution strategies that use tables and graphs including:

  • recognizing that equations with linear expressions on both sides of the equal sign (2x – 5 = x + 7) can be viewed as two equations (y = 2x - 5 and y = x + 7), where the solution to the original equation (2x – 5 = x + 7) is the point where the two lines intersect on the graph,
  • strategically selecting an efficient method to use for a given situation such as when a symbolic approach would be quick or when a calculator could be easily used to generate a graph or table to answer many questions about the relationship, and
  • generating questions for a given relationship and making sense of questions asked about variables for a given equation

Launch (Getting Started)

Connecting to Prior Knowledge

Suggested Questions

  • Display these two equations: 2x + 10 = 16 and 2x - 10 = 16. (Language) How do the equations compare? (They are the same except that 10 is added to the left side of the first equation and 10 is subtracted from the left side of the second equation.)
  • How would you begin solving these two equations? (In the first equation, you would subtract 10 from each side, since we want to “undo” the “+10.” In the second equation, you would add 10 to each side, since we want to “undo” the “-10.” Some students may note that you could divide by 2 first.)
  • In the first equation, instead of subtracting 10 from each side, could we add -10 to each side? (Yes, because subtracting 10 is the same as adding -10.)

Refer back to Completely Rational if students need more help with this.

  • How can you solve the second equation? (Some students may note that it is like you owe 10 coins. Add 10 coins to each side. Since 2x = 26, x = 13. Students may comment that this is similar to the red chips in Completely Rational.)

To help students focus on individual parts of the equations, ask the following:

  • In the Initial Challenge Set 1, how are the equations alike, and how are they different? (All of the equations have the same numbers. The only differences are the signs of those numbers.

If you did not introduce properties of equality in the summarize of the last problem, introduce the term now.

Presenting the Challenge

Ask students to consider non-whole number and non-positive situations.

  • We have not seen many negative numbers or fractions in the pouches and coins. Could we have negative numbers in a coin situation? (Answers will vary. Students might mention owing someone money or using a debit card.)
  • Could we have fractions in a coin situation? (Answers will vary. Students might say that money can be thought of in portions, for example, a quarter represents ¼ of a dollar.)

Ask the class to solve the equations, show their work, and check their answers. Have students work with a partner as they work through the problem. Distribute Learning Aid 3.3: Equivalent Equations for students to use when working on What If...? Situation C.
